author: firestar
title: Esports Aegis Platform
description: The esports ecosystem struggles with stagnating amateur and professional scenes and inefficient social networks to cultivate new talent.

f6_assessments.q0: A platform for building an Esports community on the Cardano blockchain does meet the challenge setting, especially when considering the growing popularity of Esports. Not only is the Esports community big in the traditional gaming space, but has begun to emerge in the blockchain space, on other blockchains like ethereum. If the Cardano community can create an Esports gaming space, that is designed well, it could bring lots of users and value to the space. It would be interesting however, for the proposer to compare and contrast the existing blockchain based Esports platforms/games, and identify how Cardano is uniquely suited to provide a better user experience. Also when comparing to traditional centralized Esports gaming platforms, it would be worth explaining how decentralization and DIDs better suite the Esports space? You must remember the voter will need this clearly explained, just as traditional Esports competitors will need to be sold on moving their reputations, data, and communities to the blockchain. The proposer does bullet list several points that cast a wide net, but do not specifically make the case for blockchain, and specifically Cardano based Esports.
f6_assessments.q1: Based on the information presented in the proposal, it is unlikely the project would succeed as laid out. The proposer offers no evidence to the their personal skills and experiences as relates project management or application development, nor do they offer a clearly defined and coherent strategy for seeking, finding, and employing a team of competent developers to bring the project to a minimally viable product. This is a large project to build out and would require careful building and design, as it incorporates personal information, DIDs, and a tokenized earning aspect. I would recommend phasing out the project into smaller segments over several funds. Start small with a plan to build out the basic UI/UX, and build the community up with stakeholders and other interested parties. Build a team of developers, and work out how the funding for the project will specifically be applied to a simple roadmap. Voters want to feel assured that the funds are being used judiciously, but the plan presented is too vague. I believe it is achievable, under better planning.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately the proposal does not offer anything substantial in regards to how the project will be tracked, reported on, and audited. The proposer should consider the tone of this section as it reads with a lackadaisical attitude. There is too much generalization, and not enough specificity. I would recommend the proposer provide clear and concise reporting KPIs, and how they will be communicated back to the broader Cardano community. Many proposers find success in this area by providing public GitHub repos, frequent YouTube updates, or even by spinning up websites for reporting and communicating. It is important for the community to be informed that the project is moving along,  to confirm the funds are put to a good purpose. This also has the benefit for the proposer, as it allows he/she to share struggles and shortcomings with the project. If it turns out that you  need to come back for another round of funding it will be understood why.

f6_assessments.q1:
Blake's passion for getting into active, compensated contribution in the Cardano community is evident (kudos!).  However, without a more experienced team, it seems unlikely that the project will be completed successfully. Also due to the lack of specificity on the scope, features, and near-term objectives, it bears signs (based on my own deep experience in technical projects) of being high-concept, high-scope ... and a huge attention sink.

It MIGHT be that the proposer has more specificity and that those specific details would be more actionable, but such details aren't presented here.  Proposing a clear plan is hard, and I would encourage more in the way of planning short-term, achievable milestones on 3-6 month timelines rather than the longer-term periods mentioned here.

The risks mentioned in this proposal make pretty good sense to me, but I categorize them all in the way of being risks in the product-market space.  Meanwhile, the main purpose of risk identification is to help proposers recognize where their PLAN can go wrong - and to describe how their plan has been adjusted to cope with those possible problems.  

To improve on this proposal, I'd recommend adding specificity around project-level details, identifying more specific project-level tasks & milestones and technical problems on the delivery track to nearer-term, valuable deliverables.  Also, add at least one somebody to your team that shows more direct technical and/or management experience bearing on the solution you're proposing.
f6_assessments.q2:
Checking for progress and success, and showing auditable transparency would be enabled by describing measurable activity that the project will be able to show about its real-world RESULT.  Those kinds of metrics are typically specific, measurable, and where possible, objective.  Unfortunately, this proposal doesn't address these considerations of transparency and impact as far as I'm able to assess.

The Product brief paragram "A community owned and run DID-powered profile platform that allows players..." in the proposal actually is a pretty good start on a problem statement / summary.  It reads like an early part of a newspaper article about the project.  To improve the proposal's clarity and specificity and find more in the way of impact-measures and transparency/auditability touchpoints, Blake could expand, such as an informative newspaper article would, saying more about the HOW & WHAT, perhaps identifying some specific technologies to be pulled from the shelf.  It could point to near-term achievable milestones and clear statements of the real-world impacts enabled at such milestones.

I hope these suggestions are helpful for your project-planning & execution success (and maybe for the proposing process as well)!  All good things be to you, Blake.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to create a new social network model to connect gamers and promote the e-sport scenario, making use of the DID. With this, we see that a possible success of the project would help bring more recognition to Cardano in the gamer universe, so the proposal fits the metrics of the challenge. In addition, the difficulty for an amateur player to become a professional is notorious, so a project that facilitates this procedure will be solving a real pain. In addition, as the gamer market is now one of the largest in the world, it is possible to establish numerous partnerships with the Aegis platform that would bring more visibility to Cardano's ecosystem. However, we note that the budget being requested of $50,000 is very high given the initial state of the project and the team at the moment, which ended up hampering the execution of this proposal and its possible impact. We will further analyze these factors below.
f6_assessments.q1: In fact, as stated earlier, there is a good idea here. However, it seems that more well-defined concepts have not yet been structured, so the considerable funding being requested is not justifiable. The fact that the platform uses concepts such as DID to promote greater security for player data and is self-governing are differentials, but in my opinion there are still not many incentives that can actually attract players to participate in the community, especially those who do not know blockchain technology. The incentive with native token for players to form connections is interesting, but it does not seem that this will be an initial driver in the question of building a differentiated platform in the interaction aspect. The role the NFT will play is also unclear. These indications show us that although the idea is promising, it is still a little primitive. It remains as a suggestion, then, to define some more concrete ways to promote an initial capture of players, which are the basis of the entire project. Even in the breakdown of the budget, we can see an allocation that seems relatively small for advertising (less than 20% of the budget), given that it is essential to create a large user base for the product. Also, about the team behind the project, we realized that only one professional composes it at the moment. It is a very positive factor that this professional is linked to both the software area and e-sports, two of the strongest characteristics of the project. But it would be interesting if the other professionals being sought were already reasonably located. In addition, it would be a positive factor if the $40,000 amount earmarked for development could be further detailed. The languages ​​that the developers will use could be indicated, how many hours they will work weekly or the value of the hour worked.
f6_assessments.q2: Regarding the ways to follow the progress of the project, we noticed that not many details were given so that we could have a clearer view of the progress of the results. The indication of the milestones that will be used to capture success does not often indicate results, which is important in a project with considerable complexity like this. In this context, it would be interesting to indicate the use of a tracking tool such as Jira. Another possibility would be the presentation of a public board where the objectives that have been achieved are posted with a certain frequency. Conducting periodic sprints seems to be another promising idea.

f6_assessments.q1:
Again, the main idea is interesting, but there is no detail on how the Esports Aegis Platform will be built. For example, regarding the platform description, the proposer wants to offer NFT "creation/fractionalization for tracking progress, and creation of communities". How does the proposer want to build these features? Does he plan to do some collaborations? The development of such platform can be very technical depending on the different features the proposer wants to integrate into it and it would be interesting to have a better idea on how the proposer plans to build them.

Also, the proposer is alone for the development of this platform and does not have yet the capabilities to fully develop it. He will need several collaborators but for now, it is hard to really know if the project is highly likely to be implemented successfully. I suggest to find other team members with different knowledge/profiles for the development of this platform.
f6_assessments.q2:
The "auditability" part is a copy/paste from the "Feasibility" part. I think that may be a mistake but unfortunately we have to judge based on what is written here. It would be interesting to have a plan on how the proposer wants to inform the community on the progress of the development of the platform, the success and the struggles.

The short, mid and long term vision of the platform is interesting but needs to be more detailed. For example, how many users do you plan to have after 6 or 12 months? How many NFTs sold?

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea presented in the proposal of creating a DID platform for esports gamers potentially meets parts of the challenge, but specifics are unclear. 
For one, Cardano is not mentioned as the blockchain that would be used, although this is perhaps implicit by being a proposal here.
Another is that the platform aims to be community-driven and a way for amateur
players to find experienced players to improve. This is a good idea, but I do not see how DID helps here, just because it is difficult to be an impostor coach without being discovered by the team trying to compete. So the platform would likely be driven by the excellence of its community, but it is not clear what it would offer over other established communities, or Steam or Discord.
Also, esports, while popular, is also fairly niche in the wide world of video gaming: the number of adopters to the platform could be increased by 
making casual gamers and regular achievement hunters a target as well.
f6_assessments.q1:
The project aims for DID integration in the next 6 months, and to (from previous section) "allow competitive players to create a space to upload content and posts, display verifiable statistics, and authenticate history."
However, it is not mentioned how statistics or history with games would be verified. 
The funds call for "$~40000 for development and content creation work among the team working on it."
Is "content creation" referring to the ability of competitive players to make posts and upload images/stats? Unlear.
And without clarifying what exactly this $40000 is going toward, hard to justify.
But if this is the right interpretation, there is still no mention of verifying statistics or history of competitors of games external to the platform. The other two amounts of money at $5000 for marketing and outreach are mentioned with no clear goals.
f6_assessments.q2: The milestones are vague. There's mention of making an MVP, but it is unclear what form this might take, other than providing the ability for communities to make content (for users to post content on the platform?--unclear).There's also mention of creating a roadmap, but it is not mentioned what preliminaries might need to be done on the way to forming a roadmap.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal has a high price tag, with little evidential assurance of success, and a lot of risks that could render $50,000 completely wasted. I do not give a "disagree" rating because I do think this idea has a lot of potential (specifically for the Cardano ecosystem) and the proposer appears to have a lot of the right experience to create a functional product that aligns well with the esports industry. However, I don't give a positive rating because this appears to be just an idea that is not backed by enough evidence for the success of real impact. I think the esports industry is a wildly (financially) powerful and influential industry for Cardano to break into, especially in areas of the world that are very culturally integrated with technology. However, I think this idea needs more development to have a legitimate chance at making an impact.
f6_assessments.q1: The roadmap is just not super convincing, but I think it COULD be. First of all, I want to see Blake's resume (LinkedIn). I think he's got a ton of the right technical experience (though it could use some more development) but I'm very interested in his esports/gaming experience. I wanna know how familiar he is with the esports industry as a competitor and how deep his connections go into reputable esports organizations (ideally more than just CSGO). I think it makes a big difference if the person developing the product understands esports contract agreements and talent scouting. I also think there needs to be more thought put into the marketability and long-term success of this project. For example, esports IS a billion-dollar industry, but over half of that is from regions in Asia. I would like to see what the game plan is to expand language support to offer these services to areas beyond the Western regions (which is where I assume the initial target audience is).
f6_assessments.q2: There is some concern that this proposal looks almost identical to the previous proposal. While the idea is VERY good, in my opinion, the primary thing preventing me from giving positive reviews across the board is the lack of information/evidence assuring success and development in a lot of essential areas. I think this section in particular gives the project too much "forgiveness" in the stated KPIs and success metrics. I would like to see more thorough KPIs established to determine success and progress (beyond just completion of the product). How about goals for social media following? Maybe number of high-level gamers that have expressed interest in the platform? Definitely, what esports organizations will express interest in using and watching this platform (that's a big appeal). Be thorough. Think of every little good thing that can happen in the development of this project and figure out a way to quantify that for KPI metrics. There's more work that needs to be done here than just the platform/product.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proponent identifies a major problem that aligns with the outlined challenge settings and attempts to devise a solution. But he fails to articulate his solution with the Cardano ecosystem, as he does not clearly specify through which mechanisms the Aegis Platform will function as a dApp.
Further exploration of the token issue is missing: how much will be issued? To whom and in what percentage will it be delivered? For what reasons will it be delivered? Where will the token get value from?
An answer to these questions will help the project become a crypto solution to the problem and not just a solution.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proponent states that he has sufficient skills and experience to lead this project, but does not provide links to support his statements.
The proponent has a rough idea of ​​the team members he needs to carry out the project, but for a project of this magnitude, he needs greater precision.
The budget is not outlined clearly. It needs to be broken down into more identifiable items: how many engineers will he need? How much will he pay them per hour of work? How many hours of work does he estimate they will need to finish the platform? How will he carry out the marketing activity?
Without this data, it is impossible to know if the budget is reasonable to achieve the objectives.
Another problem is the timetable. It also needs more precision in this section. Needs a more detailed breakdown indicating how he will manage to "launch the platform in 8 – 12 months".
It is understood what the proponent wants, but in the absence of these answers it is difficult to understand how he will achieve it.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proponent does not distinguish between feasibility and auditability and repeats the information in both fields.
To help the proponent, I leave below what information is expected of him in this area:
A roadmap with detailed milestones.
A clear metrics/KPIs that define the success of the proposal.
